div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,551] ALEXANDRIA, SATURDAY, JULY 21, 1906. [EIGHT PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p:
Summer Rates will be charged from 1 May to 31 October.
London £ 14. 5/ £ 9.
Maresilles £ 9. 15/ £ 6 15/
Brindisi £ 6. 15/
-
Subject to the usual 25% reduction for returning

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday until 4 June, and then every Tuesday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.

The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. Combined fare to London by sea and train de luxe via Brindisi or via Maresilles £194.11.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: Orient-Royal Mail Line.
div.p: OUTWARD to AUSTRALIA.
R.M.S. “Oroya" will leave Suez about July 27
R.M.S "Ortona" will leave Suez about August 10.
HOMEWARD to NAPLES, MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY.
R.M.S. "Orient" will leave Port Said July 31
R.M.S. “Orontes" will leave Port Said August 14
Passengers returning by the Line obtain one-third rebate off the above fares if leaving England before the end of October.
Agents. Cairo:—Thos. Cook & Son. Alexandria : —R. J. Moss & Co.—For all particulars apply
Wm. STAPLEDON & Sons, PORT SAID and PORT-TEWFIK (Suez). 30-6-906

div.head: BIBBY LINE MAIL TWIN-SCREW STEAMERS.
div.p: REDUCED SUMMER FARES MAY TO OCTOBER.
Port Said to Tilbury £ 12.15.0. and Port Said to Marseilles £ 9.0.0.
Passengers returning by the Line will be granted a rebate of 33% off the full fare i.e. Liverpool to Port Said £ 11.6.8. and Marseilles to Port Said £ 8.0.0.
OUTWARDS to COLOMBO, TUTICORIN, RANGOON. Departure from Suez.
S.S. Derbyshire, 6,636 tons, August 2.
HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON. Departures from Port Said.
S.S. Warwickshire 7,966 tons, July 24.
Agents– Cairo: THOS. COOK & SON. Suez & Port Said : WM. STAPLEDON & SONS,

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.
Passenger Tickets also issued inclusive of Railway fare through to and from Cairo. Particulars on application to
R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

div.head: P. HENDERSON & CO’s LINE.
div.p: Steamers leave SUEZ and PORT SAID fortnightly for LONDON or LIVERPOOL direct.
(Electric Light.) SALOON (Amidships) FARE £12. (Latest improvements.)
S.S. RANGOON 6000 Tons will leave PORT SAID about July 30 for Dover.
S.S. BURMA 5600 Tons will leave PORT SAID about August 11 for Devonport.
S.S. PEGU 5800 Tons will leave PORT SAID about August 18 for Dover
Due in LONDON or LIVERPOOL 12 days thereafter.
Apply WORMS & Co., Port Said and Suez. THOS. COOK & SON, (EGYPT) LD., CAIRO ;
G. J. GRACE & CO., ALEXANDRIA.

div.head: SUDAN GOVERNMENT RAILWAYS.
div.p: CAIRO-KHARTOUM SUMMER MAIL SERVICE.--SUMMER TIME-TABLE 1906.
Commencing from 1st of April, 1906, until further notice

‡Sleeping and Dining Cars. — During the month of April Sleeping and Dining Care trains leave Cairo for Luxor on Wednesdays, Mondays and Saturdays at 6.30 p.m. and Luxor for Cairo on Sundays, Tuesdays and Thursdays at 6.30 p.m.

From 1st of May 1908, these trains will be suppressed, but Dining and Sleeping Care will be attached to the ordinary night Tains from Cairo and Luxor three times a week, on the same above mentioned days. 14-6-907

div.head: Thos. Cook & Son,
div.p: HEAD OFFICE—LUDGATE CIRCUS—LONDON.
CHIEF EGYPTIAN OFFICE — CAIRO, near SHEPHEARD'S HOTEL.
Alexandria, Port-Said, Suez, Luxor, Assuan, Haifa, & Khartum.
TOURIST AND GENERAL PASSENGER AGENTS< BANKERS
Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P.&O. S.N. Co.

RESIDENTS IN EGYPT proceeding to Europe for the summer are requested to apply to our offices for information respecting their Passages, where steamer plans may be consulted and Berths secured by all Lines of Steamers to all parts of the Globe; arrangements can also be made for the collection and forwarding of their baggage and clearance at port of arrival.

CIRCULAR NOTES issued payable at the current rate of exchange in all the principal cities of Europe. Cook’s Interpreters in uniform are present at the principal Railway stations and Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their travelling tickets.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Co. leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Wady-Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum. Moderate fares.
FREIGHT SERVICE, Steamers leave Cairo every Saturday and Tuesday for Assouan and Halfa.
Special Steamers and Dahabeahs for private parties.
Special arrangements for tour in PALESTINE, SYRIA and the DESERT, Lowest Rates.
Best camp equipment in the country! 10 12-904

3 0/0 per ann. at sight; 3 1/2 0/0 per ann. for 6 months; 4 0/0 per ann. for 12 months; 5 0/0 per ann. for 3 years and over. Savings
Bank Branch receives deposits at 3 1/2 0/0 per ann., from P.T. 80 to P.T. 20,000. 19-1-907

div.p: CAPITAL: L. 3,000,000. RESERVE (ENVIRON) : L. 1,340,000.

La National Bank of Egypt reçoit des dépots à termes fixes, fait des avances et ouvre des comptes courants sur titres, valeurs et marchandises. Elle s’occupe de l’achat et de la vente d'effets sur l’Etranger, de l'escompte, ainsi que de toutes opérations de Banque. 31-12-904

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice).

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday 5 a.m. in time for express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival Trieste Wednesday about 11 a.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi & Trieste Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 20 June, 4 and 18 July, 1 and 15 Augsut, 5.
Syrian-Cyprus-Caramanian Line.

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Stands in its own grounds with garden and lawn tennis grounds at back. Over 350 rooms and 5 saloons. Magnificent salle à manger. Handsome covered promenade verandah, 80 yards long. Highest class cuisine, electric light throughout, and lifts. English comforts. Rooms and apartments at prices to suit everyone. For further particulars apply to GENERAL MANAGER, Cairo.

div.head: HOTEL BRISTOL. CAIRO.
div.p: Full South, Electric Light, opposite Esbekieh Gardens, Large Verandahs, Moderate Charges,
CHAS. BAUER, Proprietor.

The Hotel is beautifully fitted up and is in the most central part of Cairo. Terms for pension fare at the rate of ten shillings a day. Special terms for officers of Army of Occupation. 24,882-31-10-5

div.head: NEW VICTORIA HOTEL,
div.p: NOW OPEN
San Stefano, Near Alexandria, Halt No. 2.

Specially built in 1904 for a class Hotel with every modern comfort. Magnificent Dining room, Saloons, Smoking room, largo Verandahs and Garden. Electric light. MODERATE CHARGES. Ten minutes by carriage or Palais tram from Sidi Gaber.—For further particulars apply to the Manager
N.B.—Special terms for Government Officers. All rooms facing the sea.

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Yesterday was very sultry. The night was windy and the humidity has increased. The morning opens with a moderate N.W. breeze and a falling barometer. More wind is expected during the day.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: The Engish Daily Newspaper, Established 1886
Editor and Manager - - R. SMELLING
ONE PLASTRE TARIFF
Saturday, July 21, 1906.
THE TABAH BLUE BOOK

For Anglo Egyptian* by far the most interesting sections of the Bine Book dealing with the Turco Egyptian frontier dispute are Lord Cromer’s Note, dated May 21, on the attitude of the Moslem population of Egypt towards Great Britain in conception with the Frontier Question, and the remarkable letter, apparently written by a Turkish ’alim, enclosed there- with. The admirable translation of this document, which, we imagine, is the work of Mr. H. Boyle, adds a literary charm to an extra- ordinarily interesting expression of Pan-lslamio sentiment, and we commend this document to all who are under the impression that religions motives have no part in the unrest that has been remarked in Egypt during the last few months.

The Notes forwards 1 to Sir Edward Grey both by Sir Nicholas O’Conor and by Lori Cromer are of great importance. Ы. В M.'s Ambassador at Constantinople, in his Note of May 3, states that the Saltan, early in March, hid evinced a remarkable suspicion of British designs on Akaba, which, from its proximity to the Holy Places of 1 dam, is of great political л-id strategical importance. Lord Cromer explains that this suspicion on the part of his Imperial Maj »ty had its origin in the fictions industriously spread by the Pan-lslamio Press of Cairo.

The attitude of the Turkish Commanders and of the Tarkish Government was equally menacing. The Grand Vizier, telegraphing towards the end of January to the Khedive, had remarked—inter a/ta—"that if Egypt persisted in landing men and in constructing posts [This despatch was sent shortly after the arrival of the Nonr elBahr at Tabah] snob an act of disobedieoce would necessitate the employment of strong measures of ехраЫоп/’ The story of the Diana's arrival off Akaba, the determined attitude of that fine type of Tarkish soldier, Eashdi Pasha, the extraordinary behavior of the Tarkish commissioners, and the defection of two Bedoain sheikhs, are all given, and we note with some amazement that the date palm* at Tabah which were said to belong to inhabitants of Akaba were only six or seven in number and were "all dead."

The claims advanced by the Porte in April through the intermediary of Mukhtar Pasba 1 converted the question from a purely local 1 dispute to a deliberate attempt to oarry tbs Turkish borders to the Saez CanaL The unbending attitude of the Ghati and the Turkish cooptation of Rafah brought matters to a head, and the British Ultimatum of May 3 left to the Porte the decision between peace and war. It is worth noting that while throughout the dispute the attitude of the Porte had been I the reverse of conciliatory the political development of the attack on Egypt had completely outrun the Turkish military preparations. A raid was possible in the early days of May, but its execution would have been attended with grave difficulties and its failure would probably have involved the otter destruction of the raiders. Mukhtar Pasha’s three Corps d’Armée were in no position to under- take an immediate campaign against Egypt.

The attitude of the Great Powers daring the oourseof the dispute was eminently satisfactory. Sir N. O’Conor particularly mentions the sup- m port rendered by the French, Russian, Italian, and American Ambassadors, while, whatever may be said of certain irresponsible German editors and "agents,” the fact that the German Ambassador warmly and publicly congratulated Sir N.O'Conor on the success of the negotiations in the presence of the other representatives of the Powers, should dispel the belief that, on this occasion, the policy of the German Empire was directed against Great a Britain. K

We propose on another occasion to reproduce in fall Lord Cromer’s remarks concerning the Pan-lslamio Press. Meanwhile we com- mend the following epigram to the notice of Mustapha Pasha Kamel and the editor of that most sensational journal "A1 Omma” "The id Pan-lslamio Press is not the mouthpiece of opinions that exist. It creates, by every process te of misrepresentation, opinions which would otherwise be non existent,”
Today’s plague bulletin records fatal case at Alexandria and an admission to hospital at Suez.
The service to-morrow morning at 10.30 will be conducted by the Rev. Dr. Qifl'en, of the American Mission, Cairo.
The annual exhibition and distribution of prizes in St. Andrew’s upper girls’ school will take place on Monday next at 4 p.m.
The imports of coal from January 1 to July 19 amounted to 644,053 tons, as against 492,929 tons during the same period last year.
Thrее days ago a young, native woman of the Sayeda Naffeesa quarter, Cairo, took a draught of potassium, which ehemistock for some medicine, and succumbed in a few hours.

A partial eclipse of the sun will take place to-day. It will be invisible in Egypt but visible in the northern part of South America and Greenland, as well as in the northern part of Asia and the Pacific Ocean.

The Ministry of the Interior intends to add .Je district of El Marg and Zeitonn, hitherto administered by Ealioubieh Moodirieb, and the western part of Ghizth, to the thirteen kisms under the administration of the Cairo Governorate.

The stay of the Italian opera company at the Alhambra is drawing to a dose. This evening, Aida will be given. To morrow, II Barbiere di Siviglia will be given in the afternoon and Gioconda in the evening. The company will give their last performance on Monday, when La Bohème will be staged.

By the courtesy of the Egyptian Museum authorities, military people entering the Museum with the;Rev. E. J. Hardy, C. F., at 9.30 a.m. on Wednesdays, are admitted free Next Wednesday, Lieub-Col. Atkinson will point out the mummios of the Pharaohs mentioned in the Bible, and give a short account of their life and times, etc.

A Japanese sailor was attacked yesterday evening near the Marina by two natives, who attempted to rob bim. During the struggle a British soldier appeared and the allies took the two thieves prisoners to the Marina Coastguard station. The prisoners were forwarded to the Minet el-Bassal caracol, where an enquiry is now being held.

As already announced, the inauguration of the new theatre will take place t hie evening. Tomorrow morning at 10.30 the Bracelet orchestra will give a consort. Signi. Luoohini and Cairo and Signa. Ale°ei will take part in tin programme and will give for the first time the "Tiio dei Lombard’,” preceded by a violin solo. The programme will end up with the overtore from “Tannhaneer.’’

A great attraction to Cairo residents was the military concert on the terrace of the Grand Continental Hotel on Wednesday evening. A large crowd of people came to spend the evening in the open air, the restaurant was quite full, and a large number of dinners were served on well de jorated tables. The management has arranged another military concert for Wednesday next, from 8 to 11 p.m.

In the present dearth of places of amusement in Alexandria the opening of the "French Garden” to the public as a café ohantant aud promenade should be welcomed by a'l who are désirons of spending a pleasant hour or two in the cool of the evening. The garden has been prettily decorated with garlands, Hags, and hundreds of ebotrio lamps, and no pains have been spared to make the place comfortable arid a popular resort. The performance is of a varied nature and includes some excellent 1 turns,” ânsong which may be mentioned Les Frères Bonnes, who executed some marvelous acrobatic feats of strength, La belle Clemence, curd Mandroux, who gave a really first-class gymnastic display. The four Salvanos are youngsters who are more than at home on cycles and who well merited the hearty applause aaoorded. The Moustiers gavo quite a novel performance, introducing dogs dressed as elephants. These are wonder- fully well trained, and their various tricks were much appreciated. The Takitos’ droll rendering of their songs created considerable amusement. Other good items were contributediby Miss Ella, on the slack wire, Evariste au excellent xylophone player, the Sisters Gliickstern, singers and dancers, and Miles Corregioli and Melina de Gay, voca’ists. The oroheetra, under the direction of Mr. Enrico Santini, waie well op to their work, and the absence of any objeotionable waits between the turns added to the success of the enter- tainment, which was altogether a most enjoy- able one. We can safely predict a prosperous season for tke troupe.

The British Chamber of Commerce gives notice that it has commenced an employment register, which may be consulted by members requiring clerical or other assistance. Applications will be received, free of charge, from clerks and others wishing to obtain posts in Egypt. Address, Secretary, British Chamber pf Commerce, Alexandria. [Advt.]

div.head: MOSLEM & CHRISTIAN.
div.p: EXTRACTS FROM TARAH BLUE BOOK.
THE UNSIGNED LETTER.

One of the most interesting passages in the "Correspondence respecting the Turco Egyptian Frontier in the Sinai Peninsula” is a letter addressed by Lord Cromer to Sir Edward Grey in May last giving his opinion as to the state of feeling existent in Egypt during the Turco- Egyptian crisis. It is as follows :—
Cairo, May 21, 1906.

Sir,—On occasions when, as in the present instance of the Akaba frontier question, a state of some tension exists between the Ottoman Government and the European Powers, I never fail to receive a large number of letters bearing on the subject, and written both by Egyptians and by Christians residing in Egypt. These communications, which are sometimes signed, but more frequently anonymous, usually contain little more than prayers from Christians to be protected against Moslem violence, or menaces of a more or less fierce nature from Moslems as to the consequences which will ensue from the continuance of a policy hostile to His Imperial Majesty the Sultan.

These letters, from whichever side they emanate, are seldom deserving of much consideration. They are generally inspired either by unreasonable fear or by excited fanaticism. Some days ago, however', I received an unsigned letter which, both on account of the nature of its cossets and the style of its composition, appears to me to call for some degree of attention. I have the honor to in close a translation herewith.

From the language of this document, and the signs of historical and literary education which are found in it, I should judge it to be written by a member of the Ulema class, not improbably of Turkish extraction.

You will observe that the writer, in very vigorous language, defines the position of the Egyptian. People under the influence of two conflicting sentiments - Damely, on the one hand, gratitude for material benefits conferred by Christian reformers, and, on the other hand, that unquestioning devotion which every true Moslem is taught, both by tradition and education, that it is his duty and his privilege to render to the Khalif.

It will be seen that, in the opinion of the writer, there is no doubt as to which of these sentiments carries, at least in a time of stresp, the greater weight with the Moslem population. Expression is given, in brief but cordial terms, to the feeling of gratitude which the Egyptians might be expected to entertain for acknowledged benefits received ; no attempt is made to deny or to depreciate the vaine of what Egypt h s gained from British advice and assistance ; on the contrary, it is implied that, so long as nothing honors to rouse Islamic feeling from its normally quiescent etate, the Egyptians are prepared to receive with some degree of thankfulness, or at least passively, the advantages which acorne to them from British and Christian administration.

When, on the other hand, it is publicly thought and said that active differences exist between the Christian Power and the re- presentative head of the Moslem faith, the former must not for a moment be deluded by the hope that the Moslem will betray his faith from motives of material gain. The views set forth in this letter are, I believe, those which predominate in the minds of a considerable number of Egyptian Moslems.

The frame of mind here indicated con- stitute?, I venture to think, an important fdû tor in the Egyptian situation. From an historical point of view, those unacquainted with the Oriental character might very pro- bably find it a matter for surprise that the Turkish name, or the prospect of reverting in any degree to a Turkish régime should inspire in Egypt any sentiment bat that of fear. From the conquest of that country by the Sultan Selim I. up to the time of Mehemet Ali Pasha, Turkish rule in Egypt was characterized by oppressive cruelty, and by a complete disregard for the ini e-ests of the people themselves. The country was relentlessly pluodered to fill the Treasury at Constantinople, acd to enrioh the Valis aud subordinate Ottoman officials who were named and removed in rapid succession by the Sub- lime Porte. There seems to be little in this state of things wh;ch the Egyptian can re- member with pleasure, or which he would desire to see restored.

Moreover, the condition of the snrronnding Provinces of Syria and Arabia should sntfice to prove to him that the methods of Government formerly employed in his own country still remain in force elsewhere, and that no change for the better has taken place in the system pursued ly a majority of the Turkish ruling class.

It most, however, be remembered that nearly a century has elapsed since the time when Egypt was ruled directly from Constantinople. None now living can speak from personal experience of the system of government which prevailed during that period; but few can remember to have heard an account of that system from their fathers ; whilst noue who are less than from 30 to •iO years old can speak from personal experience of the abuses which occurred prior to the inauguration of the reforms und r taken on the accession of the Khedive Tewfik. A generation is now growing up which has been born under happier suspices and in и the enjoyment of a more enlightened administration. The young men of this generation, who will soon constitute the leading t c'ass in the country, are very prone tore- r gard these traditions as pure inventions, or, g at least, as malicious exaggerations, spread t abroad from interested motives. Under these circumstances, Turkish rule appears to them c in a very false light. Closing their eyes to ' numerous object lessons around them, they 1 look only to the fact that they are them- 1 selves a Moslem people, placed to some extent J under Christian guidance which they would ' gladly see exchanged for the role of their 1 co-religion its, under the direct control of 1 the Head of their Faith. I do not, of courses, ’ wish to be understood as implying that all, 1 or even a majority of the Egyptians of the j young or older generations are inspired by I this sentiment. But à strong leaven of it undoubtedly exists, and when skillfully and ' eloquently put forward it can hardly fail to spread among the mess of the people, whose i sympathies are a'.waye keenly alive to appeals directed from this quarter.

I need hardly point out the disastrous results which would inevitably ensue should these dreams ever be in any degree realized, or the bitter awakening which would await those who had indulged in them. À return to Turkish authority in this country in an active form could only mean ruin and suffering to the great mass of the Egyptian people History repeats itself, and those Egyptians who have studied the pages of the eloquent historian El Jabarti may remember the enthusiasm with which the population welcomed the army of the Grand Vizier Youssof Pasha when it entered Cairo on the departure of the French, and how soon that enthusiasm was sobered under the oppression and excesses of which they became the object. At the present day* should such an untoward event take place, its effects would be cruelly felt at once by every class, from the Khedive himself down to the humblest cultivator. That Turkish soldiers and Turkish officials possess many fine and admirable qualities is not disputed by any who know them well, but it cannot be said that the power of administering a subject province with justice and enlightenment is one of those qualities.

It may safely be asserted that in a short while nothing would remain of the present structure which has been so laboriously raised. The wealth of the country would be drained off by every form of extortionate taxation to replenish the exhausted offers of the Imperial Treasury, justice would become a thing of the past, and the mass of the population would learn by hard experience that, instead of being, as at present, the object of the keenest interest and solicitude to those in authority over them, they were regarded merely as a subject race whose doty and privilege it was to toil for the benefit of their masters. Even the upper classes, who might, perhaps, expect to profit by the change in virtue of their influence and position, would, I cannot doubt, share to a great extent the same fate. There is little sympathy between the Ottoman Turk and the Turoo-Egyptian Pasha, still less between the Turk and the rich fellah Notable. However well the Egyptian aristocracy might be treated in the first stage of the new order of things I am confident that in no long time they would find that they had exchanged the position of free citizens under a well-ordered government for that of subjects—in the fullest extent of the term—dependent on the pleasure of a practically irresponsible autocracy.

Nevertheless, in spite of there considerations, * which are too generally overlooked or little 0 understood, the names of the Khalif and his 1 Imperial capital still po sear the power to ^ awaken enthusiasm in the minds of many ® Egyptian Moslems. In so far as this sentiment 11 is founded upon pure devotion to religious * faith and loyalty to the Head of that Faith, t it cannot but excite some sympathy and b respect. Each is without doubt the frame of i mind of the writer of the inclosed letter. But 1 as regards those would-be leaders of Egyptian t thought who, without conviction and for their s own purposes, endeavor under the guise of f religious zeal to inspire the ignorant population ^ with a craving for Turkish rule, it is difficult I to speak too severely of their conduit. 1

It may confidently be said that there are many aspiration which may mors worthily and advantageously ooonpy the attention of ‘ the Egyptians, and towards the reasonable 1 attainment of which they may rely on the ‘ sympathy and coopération of their European advisers. But it must be fully reoogm'zsd that none of these aspirations could for a moment survive the accentuation of Turkish domination 1 :n the country. At the present time much is being said and written amongst tbe educated classe?, as to the development of self-governing institutions. I have frequently alluded to 1 the subject in my annual Reports. Here I need only say that, in process of time and with increasing enlightenment, it may perhaps be found possible to take some steps in this direction. But for the attainment of this end it is European assistance and guidance, Dot Turkish rale, which are required. The first result of any tightening of the Sultan’s hold over Egypt would undoubtedly be the marked limitation and diminution of the authority of the Khedive. The semi-independent position of the Khedives of E;ypt has never been viewed with friendly eyes at Constantinople, and any opportunity of restricting and oar- tailing this independence would be gladly welcomed by the Suzerain Power. Under the conditions on which the Khedivate is now established, any attempt of this nature one’d, of course, be easily frustrated. But I should be happy to think that the Egyptians generally understood -as I am convinced that many of them do understand —that the only means by which they can hope to attain and to preserve that degree of administrative autonomy to which they now aspire, is by utilizing to the fullest extent the advantages which are now placed within their reach, and discouraging any iuaidious attempts to draw closer the bond which connects Egypt with the remainder of the Ottoman Empire. To this end all who dwell on Egyptian soil should, and I trust will, work together in a community of interest ; the Egyptian, both Moslem and Christian, and the European, who, whilst benefiting himself by the development of the country, has done, and is doing, so much to improve its resources and the material condition of its inhabitants. The real utility to Egypt of this latter category wap, as is well known, for many years partly paralyzed by the existence of feelings of mutual jealously and mistrust, but these feelings seem happily to be now on the wane, a better un- distending has been established, and I trust that a time may come when the Christian and Moslem residents in Egypt, the subjects of the Siltan and those of the Powers of Europe, will be cordially united in working for the common cause—the moral and material prosperity of Egypt and its inhabitants. But, I venture to repeat, the attainment of this object is not possible so long as a willing ear is lent to those who endeavor to instill into the minds of their countrymen a futile longing for the re-establishment of a past system, which could only result in disappointment, and even disaster, to all those who came under its influence.
1 have, &c,,
(Signed) CROMER.

div.head: THE MOSLEM'S WARNING.
div.p: The following is the text of the unsigned letter referred to above : —
In the name of God, &c.
To Lord Cromer, His Britannic Majesty’s
Agent, the Reformer of Egypt.
(Translation.)

It is well known to you that the telegrams and newspapers appear each day, bringing nearer to ns, as it seems, the likelihood of grave differences between England and the Empire on matters relating to our land ot Egypt. But as the hopes of men for things desired are often disappointed, so also—for God is merciful to his creatures—Jo their fears of evil о mi to naught We pray the Almighty that it may be so now. I who write these lines in the name of "All the People of Egypt,” am not a statesman or a man of great name ; my person and my dwelling are alike unknown to you, but I feel constrained, inasmuoh as I see many foolish acts committed, and hear many foolish words spoken, to stand on my feet and say the truth, as I think God has put it into my heart.

It is often said by fool", or by those who think thereby to make favour with the great, "The ourse of God upon the Christian”; “May hell consume the unbeliever, his household and his possessions.” These are unbecoming words, for corses pollute the lips of the corset, and the camel lies in wait for the driver who mites him unjustly. At the head of this letter I call you by the name of "The Reformer of Egypt," and by this name you are known between the eeas and the deserts ; also many, but tot all, of the English who serve you have followed in your footsteps as wise children carry on the traditions of their father. He must be blind who sees not what the English have wrought in Egypt : the gates of justice stand open to the poor; the streams flow through the land are not stopped at the order of the strong ; the poor man is lifted up and the rich man palled down ; the hand of the oppressor and the briber is struck when outstretched to do evil. Our eyes see these things, and we know from whom they come. You will say : "Be thankful, Oh, men of Egypt! and bless those who benefit you”; and very many of us—those who preserve a free mind and are not ruled by flattery and guile—are thanking'. But thanks lie on the surface of the heart, and beneath is a deep well. While peaoa is in the land the spirit of Islam Bleeps. We hear the Imam ory out in the mosque against the unbelievers, bat his words pass by like wind and are lost. Children hear them for the first time and do not understand tlnm ; old men have heard them from childhood and pay no heed. But it is said. "There is war between England and Abdul Hamid Khan.” If that be so, a ohange must come. The words of the Imam are echoed in every heart, and every Moslem hears only the ory of the Faith. As men we do not love the sons of Osman ; the children at the breast know фей works, and that they have trodden down the Egyptians like dry reeds. But as Modems they are our brethren ; the Khalif holds the saored places aud the noble relios. Though the Khalif were hapless as Bayezid, cruel as Murad, or mad as Ibrahim, he is the shadow of Qod, and every Moslem must leap up at his call as the willing servant to his master, though the wolf may devour his child while he does his master’s work. The call of the Sultan is the oall of the Faith ; it carries with it the command of the Prophet (blowing’s, &c.). I and many more trust that all may yet be peace ; but, if it be war, be sure that he who has a sword will draw it, he who has a club will strike with it. The women will ory from the house-tops, "God give victory to Islam !” You will say, ‘ The Egyptian is more ungrateful than a dog, which remembers the hoard that fed him. He is foolish as the madman who pulls down the roof tree of his house upon himself.” It may be so to worldly eyes, but in the time of danged • to Islam, the Moslem tarns away from the things of this world, and thirsts only for the service of his Faith, even though be looks in the face of death. May God (His Name be glorified) avert the evil !
Signed by one, in the name of the people of Egypt.
Cairo, May 10, 1906.

div.head: NOTES FROM CONSTANTINOPLE
div.p: (From our Correspondent.)
Constantinople, July 16.

Commander C. Boaresoo, inspector of the Roumanian Maritime Service, will leave in a few days for St. Nazaire, where he will take over the new steamer Imperatiel Trajan, intend- ed for the new Constanza Constantinople Alexandria line. The vessel will arrive at Constanza on August 15, and great festivities will be held on the occasion of her christening. The inauguration of the line from Constanza to Constantinople and Alexandria has been fixed to take place on October 5.

It is stated that M. Philon, Hellenio Consul- General here, will be appointed Diplomatic Agent for Greece in Cairo. M. Naoum, the negotiator of the commercial treaty between Greeoe and Egypt, who was considered as likely to get this port, will be appointed diplomatic agent at Sofia, in succession to M. Zalacosta, who intends to retire unless the Hellenio Government gives him the promotion which he has asked for.
The Sultan ha9 given orders for the repair of the Mehemed Eini mosque and the adjoining mausoleum, at Tor.
A warrant has been is used for the arrest of Ali Hafi, who is charged with having gone to Egypt and issued prints of a seditions chv raoter.
The Hedjsz Railway Commission has re- ceived the sum of 200,000 piastres from the trustees of the late Menshawi Pasha, for the Hedjaz railway and the orphans of Ottoman soldiers.

div.head: FATAL FIRE IN TANTAH.
div.p: Early on Wednesday morning fire broke out in a house at Eafr Skarous, near Tantah. In a few minutes the flames spread to the whole building. The Moudir, the police authorities, and fire-brigade appeared on the scene early in the morning, and after a long struggle the fire was extinguished, but not before the house was destroyed. The proprietor, his wife, and his daughter, who was about to be married, were burned to death, and his two sons received serious injuries and were conveyed to hospital. The damages have not been estimated.

div.head: THE KOUBBEH ACCIDENT.
div.p: Hussein Bey Yawer, who was the only occupant of the carriage which collided with the end of the Eoubbeh Palace platform, is still in a serious condition. Besides the injuries which we mentioned in our description of the accident yesterday, he was scalded by the steam escaping from the engine, which toppled over after colliding with the buffers.

The unfortunate victim of the accident was conveyed to his home, where Dr. Shmeil and Dr. Rigazzi (who is acting fur Dr. Brossard at the Frenoh Hospital) diagnosed his injuries. Amputation, though called for by the nature of the injuries, was regarded as too dangerous, iu view of the general condition of the patient
We bear that the derailed locomotive could not be removed till late yesterday, the first crane sent down from Cairo and the second which came from Tantah being too weak to lift it.

div.head: UNION DISCOUNT CO.
div.p: We have pleasure in calling the attention of our readers to the last report and balance sheet of the Union Discount Company of London, Limited, which appeats in our oolumne to-day. This company is one of the most important Institutions doing a large and prosperous business in the London money market. The company discounts approved bank and mercantile acceptances ; receives money on deposit, and grants loans on approved negotiable securities at rates which can be ascertained on application at their office; and effects purchases and eales of Government stocks, shares and other securities on the usual terms. We understand they are doing a considerable business in this country.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. British Prince, with passengers and general cargo, sailed from Manchester on Friday and is doe at Alexandria on or about the 5th August.

div.head: NEW KHEDIVIAL HOTEL CAIRO.
div.p:
Built In 1904. Modern House. Splendid situation. Eectric Light
Lift, Pension P.T. 50. Arrangements for families.
Rooms and Breakfast P.T. 25.— Meals a la Cart

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY.
div.p: E. T. C. u. A MILITARY XI. OF R. D. F.
The military Xl.batted first and commenced badly, losing 6 wickets for 18 runs. However, some free hitting by Mr. French and Pte. Evans improved matters ; despite this they were all out for 99.
The E. T. C. commenced almost as badly as their opponents, losing 4 wkts. for 24, and despite a rather late but good effort by Blyth- mau, were all out for 75.
On the military XI. going in a second time, they were all out for 85, thanks to some good bowling by Hanley and Henley, and good fielding by all.

This left the E.T.C. the sporting task of making 110 runs in exactly an hour. They went for the runs and at 6.25 p.m. obtained them for the loss of four wickets, chiefly doe to some fine hitting by Hanley and Steele. Scores :
Military XI.

Lt. Cooper, o. Hanley, b. Blythman 2

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Lord Edward Cecil Pasha, who is now at Alexandria, leaves for Cairo next Tuesday.
Lient. Col. A. W. Roper, R. E., has arrived in Egypt from England and assumed the duties of Commanding Royal Engineer.
It is reported from Paris that H. K Mohamed Pasha Sheriff, ex Under-Secret ту to the Ministry of Foreign Affaire, is seriously ill.

The funeral of the late Antoine Bey NahmaD, French consular ageit at Tantah, took place on the 18th inst., in the presence of the Mondir and the 1st dragoman of the French Consulate at Alexandria. The African Fathers conducted the funeral service.
